newsitem.title: JORDAN: Trade minister to lead Jordan's Cairo summit team.
newsitem.headline: Trade minister to lead Jordan's Cairo summit team.

text.p: Jordan, last year's Middle East economic summit host, has decided to limit its delegation this year to ministerial level, ruling out a higher profile political team due to lack of peace progress, officials said on Sunday.

They said the cabinet approved on Saturday the composition of a 46-strong official delegation, including 15 captains of industry and commerce from the private sector and semi-governmental associations.
The delegation will be led by Trade and Industry Minister Ali Abu Al-Ragheb, they said.

Officials say the government had considered a more senior delegation headed by Prime Minister Abdul-Karim al-Kabariti but opted for ministerial representation more appropriate with its expectations of the summit.

Many businessmen warn Israel could find itself isolated by Arab businessmen at the November 12-14 conference which will group 85 states and some 25 international groups, unless it makes progress in talks with the Palestinians.

Officials say a faltering peace process and heightened tension in the region have placed unexpected hurdles in front of the coming Cairo summit, the third in a series of annual meetings originally aimed at integrating Israel.
Jordan's government, which predicted a flurry of multi-million dollar contracts at last year's summit in Amman, is wary of raising hopes unrealistically this time round.
So far 30 Jordanian businessmen have enrolled, in addition to the official delegation.

Last year Jordan's private sector submitted a prepared package of 137 projects worth $1.2 billion to the Amman summit. This year, organisers say, the private sector has not produced a summit wish-list.
The Jordanian government will submit $4 billion worth of projects, many still awaiting investors since they were first promoted at the Amman summit a year ago. -- Amman Bureau +9626-623776
